newsitem.title: UK: Delta overhauls Atlantic, Euro routes.
newsitem.headline: Delta overhauls Atlantic, Euro routes.

text.p: U.S. carrier Delta Air Lines Inc said on Tuesday it is to overhaul its transatlantic and intra-European route network with effect from April.
It said the moves should strengthen annual operating income by $62 million.
Delta's operating income, or operating profit, was $463 million in the year ended June 30 1996. The company said it would post a $60 million charge in the March quarter for the restructuring.

Delta said in a statement that the plan included starting some new services and closing others, including launching a new daily non-stop service between New York JFK and northern England's Manchester airport.
Delta is also adding new daily services between JFK and Istanbul and Madrid, making its JFK-Athens service an all year-round service and adding a second daily flight from JFK to Rome.
It is adding a daily service from Atlanta to Stuttgart and a second daily service from Atlanta to Zurich.
However, Delta said it was also closing its intra-European services linking Frankfurt with Athens, Bucharest, Istanbul, Warsaw, Moscow and St Petersburg.

"Delta service on these intra-Eureopean routes from Frankfurt was severely constrained because of international regulatory restrictions," said Michael Medlicott, Delta's vice president for Europe and Asia. "That resulted in very inefficient use of those aircraft and the financial returns on those routes were marginal," he said.
